msgSnippet: To test private methods or member variables, you can look to JUnitX (some examples are available at http://www.extreme-java.de/junitx/). Following this email
messageBody:
To test private methods or member variables, you can look to JUnitX
(some examples are available at http://www.extreme-java.de/junitx/).

Following this email is an uncompiled example of how you might test
the above code using JUnitX.

Now, taking design into consideration - the need to test private stuff
is often seen as being a code smell (just google 'testing private
methods code smell'). In essence, if your private stuff is doing
things that requires explicit testing - then maybe it is really trying
to become its own class (with its own set of tests) to which your
existing class can use (and use confidently as there are ample tests
demonstrating its proper functionality).

andrew f

``````````````````````````````````
package example;

import junit.framework.*;
import junitx.framework.*;

public class SampleTest extends PrivateTestCase
{
public SampleTest (string name)
{
super(name);
}

public void testChange()
{
Object myObject = newInstance ("example.Sample", NOARGS);
Object performChange = invokeWithKey (myObject, "change", NOARGS);

assertEquals (10, getInt(myObject, "x"));

}

}

``````````````````````````````````
